column2: Average Class Size and Class Size Distribution (Elementary)\r2016-172016-172016-172016-172017-182017-182017-182017-182018-192018-192018-192018-19\rAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# ofAverage# of# of# of\rGrade\rClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*ClassClasses*Classes*Classes*\rLevel\rSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSizeSize\r1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+1-2021-3233+\rK\r2213234233\r\r1\r2332322111\r\r2\r224233224\r\r3\r2241915223\r\r4\r2432922213\r\r5\r241424132313\r\rOther**\r\r*Numbe r of classes indicates how many classes fall into each size category (a range of total students per class).\r** “Other” category is for multi-grade level classes.\r\r\rProfessional Development provided for Teachers\r\rMeasure2017-182018-192019-20\rNumber of school days dedicated to Staff Development and Continuous Improvement4-64-64-6\r\rAt Bay View Elementary School
column3: we believe that Professional Learning opportunities are essential to ensure that every student has teachers who are\rprepared to teach to the rigor and depth required by the CA Common Core Standards.  This year our school will focus on closing the opportunity gap for\runderserved students in English Language Arts (ELA) by concentrating on improving designated and integrated English Language Development (ELD)\rinstruction.\rResearch shows a strong correlation between Collective Teacher Efficacy and Student Success.  At Bay View Elementary
column4: we see a pattern of stagnant\racademic achievement when looking at overall school achievement in ELA.  Sadly
column6: only 45% of Bay View students in Grades 3-5 tested in\rthe met or exceeded grade level proficiency range on the CAASPP ELA exam.  As such
column7: more than half of our students are not reading at grade level.\rWhen analyzing student cohort groups over time we see significant decline in student achievement in ELA.   We also see a huge disparities between our\rEnglish Language Learner (ELL) students and English proficient students with almost no ELLs achieving grade level proficiency on our state academic\rachievement tests.\rThis year’s PD Plan will meet this need by focusing on our site progress monitoring system.  We will pay particular attention to the achievement of our\rELL students and develop action research plans to address their unique learning needs.  Our 2018-2019 PD plan builds upon prior year’s work by\rexpanding our existing district-wide Professional Learning Communities (PLC) model and fine tuning our site Response to Intervention (RTI) system.\rOur meeting structures are as follows:\rWe will use the monthly district-wide English Language Development (ELD) Professional development sessions (early release days) to inform our site\rwork by introducing staff to data analysis protocols developed by the National Equity Project and spending time unpacking ELA and ELD standards and\rdetermining the implications for instruction.\rWe will meet three times a year for full day (sub-release) Student Learning Team (SLT) meetings to identify priority ELA and ELD standards and develop\rstudent goals.  We will refine our progress monitoring system by determining which common summative and formative assessments will be used to\revaluate student progress.  We will analyze our most current ELA/ELD student achievement data and create a comprehensive action plan to address the\rneeds of students at each proficiency band.\rWe will meet bi-monthly in grade level PLCs to analyze student work collected using common formative assessments to determine which instructional\rpractices are yielding the best results.\rWe meet twice a month for staff meetings which include teachers and all certificated support staff.  Here we engage in school-wide data analysis and\rengage in cross-grade level collaboration around grade level action plans.  We are striving to build more vertical alignment.\rWe augmented our professional learning capacity by providing additional training to teacher leaders at our school.   We provided sub-release training\rdays during the school year and provided summer training opportunities to teacher leaders willing to share their learnings with peers.  Additional training\rincluded:  sending several teacher leaders to Columbia Teachers College Summer Writing Institute
column8: Balanced Literacy Training provided by Momentum
column9: \rLawrence Hall of Science Next Generation Science Standards/English Language Development (NGSS/ELD) training
column10: and Silicon Valley Math Initiative\r(SVMI) training.\rThe site principal will share a summary of our professional development progress with our parent community at various community meetings including:\rSchool Site Council

column3: we believe that Professional Learning opportunities are essential to ensure that every student has teachers who are\rprepared to teach to the rigor and depth required by the CA Common Core Standards.  This year our school will focus on closing the opportunity gap for\runderserved students in English Language Arts (ELA) by concentrating on improving designated and integrated English Language Development (ELD)\rinstruction.\rResearch shows a strong correlation between Collective Teacher Efficacy and Student Success.  At Bay View Elementary
column4: we see a pattern of stagnant\racademic achievement when looking at overall school achievement in ELA.  Sadly
column6: only 45% of Bay View students in Grades 3-5 tested in\rthe met or exceeded grade level proficiency range on the CAASPP ELA exam.  As such
column7: more than half of our students are not reading at grade level.\rWhen analyzing student cohort groups over time we see significant decline in student achievement in ELA.   We also see a huge disparities between our\rEnglish Language Learner (ELL) students and English proficient students with almost no ELLs achieving grade level proficiency on our state academic\rachievement tests.\rThis year’s PD Plan will meet this need by focusing on our site progress monitoring system.  We will pay particular attention to the achievement of our\rELL students and develop action research plans to address their unique learning needs.  Our 2018-2019 PD plan builds upon prior year’s work by\rexpanding our existing district-wide Professional Learning Communities (PLC) model and fine tuning our site Response to Intervention (RTI) system.\rOur meeting structures are as follows:\rWe will use the monthly district-wide English Language Development (ELD) Professional development sessions (early release days) to inform our site\rwork by introducing staff to data analysis protocols developed by the National Equity Project and spending time unpacking ELA and ELD standards and\rdetermining the implications for instruction.\rWe will meet three times a year for full day (sub-release) Student Learning Team (SLT) meetings to identify priority ELA and ELD standards and develop\rstudent goals.  We will refine our progress monitoring system by determining which common summative and formative assessments will be used to\revaluate student progress.  We will analyze our most current ELA/ELD student achievement data and create a comprehensive action plan to address the\rneeds of students at each proficiency band.\rWe will meet bi-monthly in grade level PLCs to analyze student work collected using common formative assessments to determine which instructional\rpractices are yielding the best results.\rWe meet twice a month for staff meetings which include teachers and all certificated support staff.  Here we engage in school-wide data analysis and\rengage in cross-grade level collaboration around grade level action plans.  We are striving to build more vertical alignment.\rWe augmented our professional learning capacity by providing additional training to teacher leaders at our school.   We provided sub-release training\rdays during the school year and provided summer training opportunities to teacher leaders willing to share their learnings with peers.  Additional training\rincluded:  sending several teacher leaders to Columbia Teachers College Summer Writing Institute
